questions.text: A 27-year-old woman has suffered a gunshot wound to her mid abdomen. After examining the patient's angiogram, a trauma surgeon locates the source of bleeding from pairs of veins that typically terminate in the same vein. Which of the following veins are damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Left and right hepatic veins
Sol:
• The right and left hepatic veins drain into the inferior vena cava.
• The right gastroepiploic vein drains into the superior mesenteric vein, but the left one drains into the splenic vein.
• The right gonadal and suprarenal veins drain into the inferior vena cava, whereas the left ones drain into the left renal vein.
• The right colic vein ends in the superior mesenteric vein, but the left one terminates in the inferior mesenteric vein.

questions.text: A 65-year-old CEO of a MNC received a severe blow on his head that caused a depressed fracture of his frontal bone. He was admitted in the hospital and discharged after 72 hours of observation. He joined his duty but in a few days the office staff  noticed that CEO’s social behaviour has changed dramatically. He no more dresses himself properly and lacks initiative and drive. He also lacked inhibition and one day he was seen urinating in the dustbin of his office. Which part of the brain is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Prefrontal area
Exp: The abnormal behaviour and personality changes noticed in CEO were due to a severe lesion involving the prefrontal areas of both frontal lobes of cerebrum secondary to the depressed fracture of the frontal bone.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with occasional headaches. On examination, several pigmented spots on his trunk are seen with few rubbery cutaneous tumors on his neck. The cells composing these skin tumors most likely originated from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Neural crest

Neurofibromatosis Type I (NF1, or von Recklinghausen's disease) is a common autosomal-dominant disorder. Cutaneous and subcutaneous neurofibromas are common in this condition and are tumors of Schwann cells, which are embryologically derived from the neural crest

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with left arm clumsiness. Physical examination reveals motor weakness and increased muscle tone in the left arm. Specifically, with passive extension of the left arm there is initial resistance then sudden release when maximum extension is reached. Pathology within which of the following brain structures is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer(B)

Exp:
• This patient has "clasp knife spasticity," characterized by initial jerking resistance to passive extension followed by sudden release of resistance. This form of spasticity is typical of an upper motor neuron lesion.
• Potential sites for upper motor neuron lesions include the corticospinal tracts of the spinal cord; the medulla, pons and midbrain; the internal capsule; or the precentral gyrus (primary motor cortex). Of these, the internal capsule is the only structure labeled above (Choice B).

• In general, upper motor neuron lesions cause spastic paresis, hyperreflexia, and a positive Babinski sign. The clasp knife phenomenon is a form of spasticity that results from a lack of upper motor neuron inhibitory control on the spinal muscle stretch reflex arc.

questions.text: A patient is unable to prevent anterior displacement of the femur on the tibia when the knee is flexed. Which of the following ligaments is most likely damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Posterior cruciate

Sol:   

• The posterior cruciate ligament is important because it prevents forward displacement of the femur on the tibia when the knee is flexed.

• The anterior cruciate ligament prevents backward displacement of the femur on the tibia.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman received a first-degree burn on her neck, arm, and forearm from a house fire. Which of the following skin structures or functions is most likely damaged or impaired?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Exocrine gland secretion
Sol:
• Skin has sweat glands and sebaceous glands, which are exocrine glands. Skin produces vitamin D, but it does not produce a trophic hormone and does not produce vitamin A.
• In addition, skin contains no general somatic efferent (GSE) and parasympathetic general visceral efferent (GVE) nerve fibers.

questions.text: The core body temperature of an experimental animal was raised from 98 degrees F to 106 degrees F by passive heating. Eventually, his body temperature dropped to 99 degrees F. What is the gain of the temperature control system in this animal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer  (D)

-7
Gain = correction/ error
Since the temperature has been lowered from 106 to 99 degrees F, the correction is -7. But
the corrected temperature is 1 degree F higher than set point, the error is +1.
Therefore, gain = -7/+1 = -7

questions.text: A 73-year-old man comes to the emergency department complaining of chest pain, shortness of breath on exertion, and syncope. The patient has poorly managed hypercholesterolemia and a 10-year history of hypertension. Physical examination:- Temp- 37°C, Pulse- 85/min, Respiratory rate- 18/min, BP- 100/75 mm Hg. A systolic murmur is present, loudest over the aorta and peaking at mid systole. Palpitation of the carotid upstroke reveals a pulse that is both decreased and late relative to the apical impulse. Palpation of the chest reveals an apical impulse that is laterally displaced. Lungs are clear, and there are no rales. ECG: Left axis deviation but no abnormalities in the ST segment. Chest radiography: Enlarged left ventricle and calcification of the aortic valve. Doppler ultrasonography: A greatly increased velocity of flow during the systolic portion of the cardiac cycle. The left atrium and left ventricle chambers are enlarged, and left ventricular hypertrophy is present. Cardiac enzymes: CK-MB, troponin I, and myoglobin levels are normal. Which of the following PV loops corresponds with the condition described above? Abnormal loops are in red.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The patient has aortic stenosis. In aortic stenosis, the LV pressure- volume loop is characteristically described as a “tall and narrow” loop. The loop is tall because the LV has to exert much more pressure to open a stenosed valve. Since the stroke volume is decreased in this patient, the loop is narrow.

choices.text: Increased renal conversion of 25- hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25- dihydroxycholecalciferol
Increased reabsorption of calcium in DCT
Increased reabsorption of inorganic phosphorus in the PCT

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman is referred to an endocrinologist due to high calcium levels found during treatment for a fracture of her femur. The patient’s femur was fractured at the midshaft by a compression. The injury should not have been severe enough to break the bone. During treatment, the patient was noted to have high calcium levels and was referred for further evaluation. Physical examination reveals the following:- T 37°C, P 80/min, R 15/min, BP 116/76 mm Hg, BMI 26. The patient appears healthy and exercised regularly before the injury. The left femur is immobilized, and the injury appears to be healing well. 
Plasma analysis: 

● Serum calcium: 14.2 mg/dL 

● Serum phosphorus (inorganic): 2.1 mg/dL

● PTH levels: 2200 pg/mL  

Which of the following is not seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased reabsorption of inorganic phosphorus in the PCT

The patient has elevated plasma calcium levels (normal: 8.4-10.2 mg/dL), decreased plasma phosphorus (normal: 3.0-4.5 mg/dL) and increased PTH levels (normal: 230-630 pg/mL), leading to a diagnosis of hyperparathyroidism. PTH increases calcium reabsorption in the DCT but decreases phosphorus reabsorption in PCT (phosphaturic action of PTH).

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after camping in the winter with some friends. He became cold and wet during a rainstorm during the night and, in the morning, his friends had difficulty waking him. Physical examination:- Temp 32°C (rectal), Pulse 50/min, Respiratory rate 8/min, BP 90/70 mm Hg, BMI 26. The patient is conscious but confused. His skin is pale, and the lips, fingers, and toes are cyanotic and cold. Corneal reflexes are diminished. The patient is shivering uncontrollably and has difficulty speaking. ECG shows a sinus bradycardia. 

Which of the following is not a major physiological mechanism in adults to diminish heat loss or enhance heat gain when the ambient temperature is lower than body temperature?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Metabolize brown adipose 
The clinical presentation is that of hypothermia. 
When the ambient temperature is lower than the body temperature, there is a tendency to lose heat. The major mechanism of heat loss is by radiation. Heat loss tends to cause a fall in the core body temperature. The following physiological mechanisms/ behavioural changes help to diminish heat loss or enhance heat gain:- 
• Increased sympathetic discharge which decreases cutaneous blood flow
• Shivering 
• Huddle or take ball posture 
• Move to warmer environment 
• Increase activity and movement 
• Increase metabolic rate
• Piloerect
• Metabolize brown adipose (infants)
Non- shivering thermogenesis in brown fat is not a major mechanism of heat gain in adults. It contributes hardly 10-15% of the total heat generated in adults.

choices.text: Medial portions of the left hemisphere motor cortex
Lateral portions of the left hemisphere motor cortex
Medial portions of the right hemisphere motor cortex
Lateral portions of the right hemisphere motor cortex

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to his physician complaining of a drooping eyelid and facial twitching on the left side of his face. He first noticed the symptoms about 6 hours ago, but they have continued to worsen. He is now having trouble tasting and is drooling from the left corner of his mouth. The patient has extreme left-sided facial weakness and paralysis. He is unable to blink his left eye. The patient has not had any neurologic problems in the past, although he did have the flu 3 weeks ago. Vital signs: T 38.2°C, P 80/min, R 18/min, BP 120/76 mm Hg.

Output from what region of the motor cortex is no longer reaching the facial muscles?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lateral portions of the right hemisphere motor cortex

The patient’s left side is affected. The lesion, therefore, lies in the face area of the right side motor cortex which is the lateral portion of right side motor cortex.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes in for her regular check-up and complains about having a constant thirst and getting up frequently in the night to urinate. The patient has a history of high blood pressure. Her blood pressure has remained high regardless of medications prescribed or dosage. Vital signs: Temp- 37°C, Pulse- 85/min, Resp rate- 17/min, BP 145/110 mm Hg, BMI 32. 

Basic metabolic panel: 

Glucose: 95 mg/dL (normal: 70-110 mg/dL) 

Calcium: 9.2 mg/dL (normal: 8.4 to 10.2 mg/dL) 

Sodium: 146 mEq/L (normal: 136 to 145 mEq/L) 

Chloride: 100 mEq/L (normal: 95-105 mEq/L) 

Potassium: 3.2 mEq/L (normal: 3.5 to 5.0 mEq/L) 

Plasma aldosterone (recumbent): 25 ng/dL (normal: 2-16 ng/dL) 

Plasma renin activity: 0.8 ng/mL/hr (normal: 1.9 to 3.7 ng/mL/hr) 143. 

The decreased plasma renin activity is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Hypertension 
The patient has hyperaldosteronism which causes sodium and water retention and an elevated blood pressure. The most potent stimuli for secretion of renin are hypovolemia and hypotension. Increase in blood pressure decreases renin secretion.

choices.text: Accumulation of fat in the liver

questions.text: A 45 year old male is chronic alcoholic for past 15 years. He has tendency to faint often. His skin is dry and itchy. Following  metabolic adaptation are seen in chronic alcoholism except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

High NAD+ level 
 Oxidation of ethanol by alcohol dehydrogenase leads to excess production of NADH. 
 The increased (NADH/NAD+) ratio also causes increased (lactate/pyruvate) , resulting in  lactic acidemia, which decreases excretion of uric acid, aggravating gout.

questions.text: DNA can be fragmented using restriction endonuclease enzyme. Fragments of different size can be separated by a technique called electrophoresis. Which among the following fragments will be found maximally towards the negative pole during DNA gel electrophoresis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

5000 bp

Explanation: DNA itself is negatively charged and when gel electrophoresis is done, the largest fragment will move most slowly and hence will be found maximally towards the negative side.

questions.text: Aerobic and anaerobic glycolysis differ in terms of energy production and end product which is formed. In addition to glucose there are many other carbohydrates as well which produce ATP by using steps of glycolysis.  Which of the yields 3 molecules of ATP under an-aerobic metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Glycogen

Glycogenolysis produces glucose-1-phosphate, which enters the glycolysis in the form of glucose-6-phosphate.
Total ATP produced in anaerobic condition is 4, but as the consumption is only for 1 ATP, net production is 3 ATP.

choices.text: Conversion of pyruvate to lactic acid
Conversion of pyruvate to acetyl co A

questions.text: Anaplerotic and cataplerotic reaction need to be in balanced form for maintaining the homeostasis of metabolism. Which of the following is most abundant anaplerotic reaction in mammal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Conversion pyruvate to oxaloacetate 		
Anaplerotic reactions are those reactions which provide TCA intermediates.
Conversion pyruvate to oxaloacetate is the most important anaplerotic reaction in human.

questions.text: Vitamins are micronutrients which are mostly required from outside. There are few exception to it. Which of the following vitamin is synthesized from an amino acid in vivo in the body by humans?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Niacin

Tryptophan is the amino acid which can produce niacin in Kynurenine pathway which is dependent upon vitamin B6. 
Half of the total requirement of niacin is met by its synthesis from tryptophan. In deficiency of B6 patient will have pellagra like features due to lack of niacin synthesis. This is called as B6 pellegra.

questions.text: A 56-year-old reports reduced exercise tolerance over the past 5 years. In the past year he has noted chest pain after ascending a flight of stairs. He smokes 2 packs of cigarettes per day. On examination he has a blood pressure of 155/95 mm Hg. His body mass index is 30. Laboratory findings include a total serum cholesterol of 245 mg/dL with an HDL cholesterol of 22 mg/dL. Which of the following abnormalities is he most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Atherosclerosis. He has multiple risk factors for atherosclerosis, including his weight, smoking, hypertension, and high total cholesterol with low 'good' HDL cholesterol. His findings suggest coronary artery disease with risk for an acute coronary syndrome.

choices.text: Inability to stop cell cycle at G1S check point
In ability to detect DNA errors

questions.text: A 5 year child presents with diminished vision in the left eye. Physical examination reveals multiple hyperpigmented patches all over body. An imaging suggests there is a tumor in the eye. A microscopic examination of the tumor shows pleomorphic cells with prominent nucleoli and a black coloured  intracellular pigment. Genetic analysis shows the child has an inherited mutation leading to such lesions. Which of the following cellular pathogenesis is leading to increased cancer in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A nucleotide excision repair abnormality. The child is having hyperpigmented lesions and an ocular tumor suggestive of a melanoma ( black coloured pigment = melanin) which is suggestive of a Xeroderma pigmentosa.

questions.text: A 35 year old woman presents with nodule in front of neck, FNAC is suggestive of papillary carcinoma of thyroid, her elder brother was diagnosed of colon cancer at the age of 45, her cousin also had a renal cell carcinoma at the age of 55 years. Her mother had breast carcinoma at 48 years. which of the following explains the increased risk of cancer in these people?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Multifactorial. The age of onset of cancer in these is not young which is expected in options a and b thus a multifactorial ( inherited and environmental causes ) could be a possibility. If it was inherited cancer syndromes usually there will be multifocal carcinomas or multiple carcinoma in the same patient. Here age of onset is 45,48,55 which are most likely suggestive of sporadic thus the answer.

choices.text: A culture positive for Mucor mycosis
A Sputum positive for TB PCR
A linear pattern on IF on kidney biopsy

questions.text: A 48 year old lady presents with persistent cough for last 4 months, which is not controlled with over the counter anti tussive. The cough is dry and is not associated with sputum. She had few episodes of epistaxis in the last few months but she insists that is not the major problem, Examination shows few purpuric rashes on skin, the bridge of the nose is depressed and auscultation shows focal areas of crepitations bilaterally. CT chest shows multiple infiltrated in the lungs bilaterally. Hb 10g/dL, TLC is 15000, Platelet count 1.8L/ cu.mm, CRP is 15, ESR is 35/1st hour, Urine Dipstick shows Protein 2+, microscopy is awaited. A biopsy from the lung is as shown in the image. Which of the following investigation is likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cresents on Renal biopsy. The patient is having lung involvement, Upper respiratory tract involvement ( saddle nose) and proteinuria and petechiae and epistaxis ( bleeding from small vessels) all features are suggestive of a Granulomatosis with polyangiitis ( Wegner’s Granulomatosis) which will present as a rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis ( Cresentic on histology)

questions.text: A 55 year diabetic patient on insulin presents with severe abdominal pain, fever. Physical examination shows diffuse guarding of abdomen. Temperature 38.4, pulse 102, BP 110/70, the patient appears to be flushed and multiple patechaie throughout the body. Clinically you are suspecting a perforation peritonitis leading to sepsis and DIC secondary to diabetes and want to treat the patient accordingly. You are asked to draw samples for CBC, D-Dimers, blood grouping cross matching, blood culture, Blood sugar and lactate levels. Which of the following vaccutainers and in which order (from left to right) you would be drawing blood? (Choose Option From Image)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

first to be drawn is culture after Blue ( for D Dimers) next will be red ( for cross match) followed by levander for CBC, Blood grouping and the last will be gray ( for Blood glucose and lactic acid)

choices.text: Emergency platelet transfusion with fluids and antipyretics

questions.text: A 10 year old boy is having fever and arthralgia for last 5 days, temperature is 101 F, pulse 88, BP 120/82, clinically oral mucosa appears dry. He had an episode of epistaxis after he tried to remove the secretions from the nose which stopped on its own without any medical treatment. Antibodies to NS1 antigen is positive. Platelet count is 15000/cu.mm, TLC is 7000. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Fluids and antipyretics. The child is having dengue fever . platelet transfusion is indicated if there is spontaneous bleeding is present or prophylactically if count is < 10000. This child has neither thus we will not transfuse platelets. He has to be treated for fever and dehydration( dryness of mouth) thus fluids and antipyretics. Antibiotics have no role in viral infection like Dengue.

questions.text: Parents of a 3 year child have notices a vague lump in their 3 year child’s left testes. Clinical examination shows both the testes have descended normally and there is a firm swelling in the left testis. USG confirms features suggestive of a neoplastic lesion. An Orchidectomy was performed. And the histology is as shown in the image. The tumor cells were negative for cytokeratin and leucocyte common antigen but positive for desmin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Rhabdomyosarcoma. A testicular tumor positive for Desmin ( which is a muscle marker) is suggestive of embryonal RMS, which presents as  a small round cell tumor as in the image.

choices.text: A 4 year child, with high grade fever and leucocytosis
A 55 year male with epistaxis and a nasal polyp
A 15 year child with mediastinal mass
A 32 year old with cervical lymphadenopathy

questions.text: Immunohistochemical analysis from a neoplasm shows cells are positive for CD45 (LCA), CD3, Cd5, CD10 and TdT. Which of the following would be most likely clinical presentation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A 15 year child with mediastinal mass. The immunohistochemistry suggests that the neoplasm is an acute T lymphoblastic lympoma/ leukaemia. TALL most commonly presents as lymphoma (mediastinal Mass) in 2nd decade of life around puberty.

choices.text: No resolution of anemia due to folate trap
Resolution of anemia but patients developing parasthesia
Resolution of anemia and increase in B12 levels

questions.text: A 48 year old woman presents with easy fatigue for the last 1 year. She has been taking oral iron, B12 and multivitamin tablets with no improvement. She has no altered sensation or any motor deficits. Neurological examination is normal Peripheral blood examination as shown in the image. A serum B12 levels 230pg/ml (normal 200-900) and folate levels 1ng/ ml ( normal 4-20 ng/ml). Patient was put on oral folate as a part of treatment. Which of the following is expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Resolution of anemia but patients developing paraesthesia. The patient is having folic acid deficiency, if folic acid deficiency are treated with Folate alone ( especially in borderline B12 patients) the Adenosyl cobalamine ( required for neurological homeostasis) will be used for erythropoiesis since it was deficient during anemic phase thus creating a pseudo deficiency in neurons causing neurological manifestations.

questions.text: An internare transfusing whole blood to an 48 year old woman who is about to undergo hysterectomy for fibroids. Her vitals are normal to begin with, 15 minutes into transfusion she develops urticaria and rashes, intern immediately stop transfusion and administers IM antihistaminics and is waiting for the patient to respond. However the patient now presents with difficulty to breathe, slurred speech, and a heavy voice, his BP is no 100/70. What is the best next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

IM adrenalin.. the patient is having an anaphylactic shock ( low BP with slurred speech and heavy voice suggestive of laryngeal and angioedema).

questions.text: A 5 year boy presents with fever and  rashes on the cheek and itching for 2 days. Examination shows there are blisters on the skin containing clear fluid. He was prescribed paracetamol, antihistaminic and a calamine lotion to be applied on the blisters. 5 days later although the fever has subsided the child has red painless non itchy spots as seen in the image throughout the body. Although his vitals were normal a CBC was performed now shows a TLC 11000, Hb 12 g/dL, Platelet count 38000/cu.mm What is the likely explanation? Which of the following is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura. The child is having petechiae over the body (image) after viral illness (clinically s/o chicken pox) with thrombocytopenia is acute ITP. Option B will present as adrenal insufficiency in meningococcal infection, option C will happen if aspirin was prescribed in children. DIC should have spontaneous bleeding and reduced BP which is not the case.

questions.text: A 32 year lady presents with a lump in right breast. Examination shows the lump is hard adherent to the skin. Since her mother also has history of breast cancer a genetic test for inherited mutation comes out to be positive for BRCA-1. Which of the following is true about the assay of her breast tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ER- PR- Her 2 Neu –. Inherited BRCA1 mutations most likely have Triple negative breast carcinoma, BRCA 2 on the contrary have ER positive tumors.

choices.text: Detect DNA errors at G1S and G2 M check point

questions.text: A 26 year old presents with bleeding per rectum, colonoscopy shows few polypoidal masses in the colon which do not have a definitive stalk. A biopsy was performed from one of the lesion is as shown in the image. The patient family history of cancer in mother having endometrial carcinoma. You start suspecting a familial cancer syndrome due to an inherited mutation. Which of the following is the cellular function of the mutated gene in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Correct DNA errors. The patient is having a sessile serrated adenoma ( on histology saw toothed glands are seen) and history of mother having endometrial cancer raises suspicion of Lynch Syndrome which occurs due to Mismatch repair abnormalitits (MSH-6, MSH 2 MLH 1 mutations).

questions.text: A know patient of sickle cell anemia presents with black discolouration of distal finger as shown in the image. True about the process are all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dense neutrophilic infiltrate will be seen on microscopy in black areas. The image is of a gangrene which is a coagulative necrosis, since there is no blood supply to the affected area even neutrophils cant survive, thus absent Neutrophils will be feature.

questions.text: A patient presents cough weight loss and hemoptysis. Imaging shows a lung tumor biopsy from lung carcinoma shows tumor cells positive for P40 and P63. Which of the following is likely to be manifestation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

An association with smoking. The lung tumor is positive for P40 and P63 which are markers for squamous cell carcinoma, which is associated with smoking

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman suffering from osteoporosis had been receiving alendronate and vitamin D supplementation for 2 years. Recent dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry showed a big decrease in bone density. The patient’s history was sig- nificant for a femur fracture 2 months earlier and a rib frac- ture 1 month earlier. Which of the following drugs is most likely to increase bone density in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Teriparatide is a recombinant analogue of parathyroid hormone (PTH) with physiological actions equal to those of the natural hormone. PTH exerts both catabolic and anabolic effects on bone. Catabolic effects prevail with chronically elevated PTH; there is a net increase in bone resorption. An- abolic effects prevail with intermittent low doses of PTH; there is a net increase in bone formation (by increasing osteoblast number and activity) without stimulating bone resorption. This has led to the approval of teriparatide for the treatment of osteoporosis. The drug is reserved for advanced osteoporosis when bisphosphonate therapy has failed, ex- treme bone loss has already occurred, and/or fracture has already occurred, as in this case. Teriparatide is the only cur- rently available therapy that results in net bone deposition. 
B Estrogens are used for prevention, not for treatment, of osteoporosis only in postmenopausal women who need estrogen treatment for the management of menopausal symptoms. 
C Because alendronate was not effective, the use of an- other bisphosphonate would be irrational. Bisphosphonates are considered antiresorptive agents as opposed to bone anabolic agents. 
D Calcitonin does not consistently decrease hip fracture risk and does not increase bone density.

questions.text: A 57-year-old obese man was diagnosed with type 2 dia- betes mellitus. The patient had been suffering from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease for 5 years and from hyper- tension for 3 years. His current therapy included ipratropium and captopril. Which of the following antidiabetic drugs would be relatively contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Biguanides can cause lactic acidosis and therefore are rel- atively contraindicated in all conditions that predispose to acidosis. This patient is suffering from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and is under treatment with an angio- tensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. The respiratory disease predisposes to respiratory acidosis, and ACE inhibi- tors predispose to metabolic acidosis because they lower aldosterone serum levels. 
A, C, D None of these drugs are contraindicated in this patient.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy recently diagnosed with asthma started a therapy that included inhaled fluticasone. Which of the following molecular actions most likely contributed to the therapeutic effect of the drug in the patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Current therapeutic strategies available for the treatment of asthma include inhibition of eicosanoid biosynthesis (glu- cocorticoids), inhibition of leukotriene biosynthesis (zileu- ton), activation of β2 receptors (β2 agonists), and blockade of leukotriene receptors (zafirlukast). The glucocorticoid- induced inhibition of eicosanoid biosynthesis is mediated by the inhibition of phospholipase A2, the enzyme that releases arachidonic acid from membrane-bound phospholipids. 

A This would be the mechanism of action of ipratropium. B This would be the mechanism of action of zafirlukast These receptors are not involved in bronchodilation. F Activation (not inhibition) of lipocortin biosynthesis mediates the glucocorticoid-induced inhibition of phospho- lipase A2.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man who has been receiving his first course of chemotherapy for a non-Hodgkin lymphoma still complains of recurrent nausea and vomiting despite antiemetic medi- cation with ondansetron, dexamethasone, and aprepitant. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate to add to the patient’s antiemetic regimen at this time?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dronabinol is a Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinol, the most active cannabinoid from cannabis. Its mechanism of antiemetic action is still uncertain, but the drug likely activates specific cannabinoid receptors in the vomiting center. Because of the availability of more effective agents, dronabinol is uncom- monly used in patients receiving cancer chemotherapy, but can be a useful addition when other antiemetic medications are not effective, as in this case. 
A−C These drugs are devoid of antiemetic properties.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman complained to her physician of bleed- ing gums. The woman had been receiving her third cycle of chemotherapy for metastatic ovarian cancer. A blood analy- sis showed the following results: red blood cell count 3.2 × 106/mm3 (normal, female 3.5−5.5 × 106/mm3), mean corpus- cular volume 96 fL (normal 80−100 fL), hemoglobin 9 g/dL (normal, female > 12 g/dL), neutrophil count 4600/mm3 (normal 3000−7000/mm3), platelet count 7000/mm3 (nor- mal 130,000−400,000/mm3). A hematopoietic agent was administered intravenously. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The patient’s lab results indicate severe thrombocytopenia, likely due to cytotoxic anticancer chemotherapy. Oprelvekin, the recombinant form of interleukin-11, has been approved for treatment of severe thrombocytopenia due to chemo- therapy for nonmyeloid malignancies. 
A Filgrastim is human granulocyte colony-stimulating fac- tor that stimulates the production of granulocyte progenitor cells. The normal neutrophil count indicates that there is no granulocytopenia. 
B Erythropoietin is given when the anemia is hypoprolif- erative (i.e., due to a deficient response to cytokine humoral stimuli). There is no evidence that the patient’s anemia is hypoproliferative.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman consulted her physician because of a postpartum breast infection. A Gram stain of the pus re- vealed gram-positive bacteria, and a susceptibility test showed resistance to all β-lactam antibiotics. Which of the following bacteria was most likely the offending pathogen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman complained of blurred vision and inability to distinguish green objects from red objects. The woman, recently diagnosed with cavitary pulmonary tuber- culosis, had been receiving a three-drug combination regi- men for 2 months. An eye examination indicated a narrowing of her visual field. Which of the following drugs most likely caused these adverse effects?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman recently diagnosed with onychomy- cosis started a treatment with terbinafine. Inhibition of which of the following enzymes most likely mediated the thera- peutic effect of the drug in the patient’s disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: A 6-year-old hospitalized child complained of pain when urinating. A urine sample was cloudy and red. The child, di- agnosed with neuroblastoma, had begun a chemotherapy program 5 days earlier. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The patient presented with gross hematuria, which can be either painless or painful. Whereas the former can have many causes, painful hematuria is usually due to inflamma- tory disease of the urogenital tract (cystitis and prostatitis), renal infarction, or nephrolithiasis. Renal infarction and renal calculi are unusual in a very young child. Cyclophosphamide can cause bladder mucosa edema, ulcerations, and minor to severe hemorrhage. This toxicity is believed to be due to me- tabolites of cyclophosphamide, including chlorethylaziridine and acrolein, which are formed by hepatic microsomes and excreted in the urine. They can concentrate in the bladder and cause mucosal damage. The incidence of hemorrhagic cystitis from cyclophosphamide administered at conven- tional doses is unknown, but in patients receiving high-dose regimens, it is about 10%. 
A: Adverse effects of these drugs do not include neph- rotoxicity. 
B, E Cisplatin and, very rarely, doxorubicin can cause neph- rotoxicity, but hemorrhagic cystitis has not been reported.

questions.text: A 57-year-old obese woman had low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol of 350 mg/dL (normal < 130 mg/dL) despite 3 months of therapy with lovastatin. The physician decided to add to the patient’s regimen a drug that acts by increasing the elimination of bile acids. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cholestyramine is a bile acid−binding resin. Drugs of this class are highly positively charged (cholestyramine is a qua- ternary amine) and bind negatively charged bile acids in exchange with Cl−. Because of their large size, resins are not absorbed, and the bound bile acids are excreted in the stool. In this way, enterohepatic circulation of bile acids is pre- vented (normally, more than 95% of bile acids are reab- sorbed; their excretion is increased up to 10-fold when the resins are given).

choices.text: Increased IgM; Decreased IgG, IgA, IgE

questions.text: A 6-month-old is male child is admitted for sinopulmonary infection. History reveals that he was suffering from the same type of infections twice. His pediatrician suspected an immune deficiency etiology and referred the child to a pediatric immunologist for further workup of recurrent sinopulmonary infections which have not abated despite adequate treatment. During the workup, flow cytometry demonstrates a decrease in normal CD40L cells. Based on these findings, the immunologist decides to pursue a further workup and obtains immunoglobulin levels. Which of the following immunoglobulin profiles is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increased IgM; Decreased IgG, IgA, IgE
• It’s a case of Hyper IgM Syndrome.
• Hyper-IgM syndrome is an immunodeficiency characterized by B and T cell dysfunction. It is most commonly caused by defective CD40L on helper T cells which prevents class switching. It often presents with severe pyogenic infections and recurrent sinopulmonary infections early in life. It should be noted though that this is a non-specific finding that is associated with numerous other causes such as viral infection. Immunoglobulin levels reveal increased IgM and decreased IgG, IgA, and IgE. The treatment is administration of IVIG. 
• Increased IgM and decreased IgG, IgA, and IgE is characteristic of hyper-IgM syndrome, which causes severe pyogenic infections in the first months of life.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician after developing fever and a sore throat. The patient recently entered day care and similar symptoms have been reported in several of the other children. Physical examination shows exudative pharyngitis and enlarged anterior cervical lymph nodes as shown in the image. A rapid antigen detection test confirms the diagnosis of streptococcal throat infection. Her condition resolves with antibiotic therapy. Several weeks later. she is re-exposed to Streptococcus pyogenes. The bacteria penetrating beyond the surface epithelium are immediately A coated with preformed lgG antibodies. Which of the following substances acts in the most similar manner to lgG antibodies to facilitate phagocytosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Complement C3b
• Opsonization occurs when host proteins such as immunoglobulins or complement bind to the surface of foreign cells (eg. bacteria) to promote phagocytosls.
•  The most important opsonins (coating proteins) are immunoglobulin (lg) G and complement C3b. but mannose-binding lectin and C-reactive protein can also opsonize cells. After opsonins are bound to the cell surface. they act as a handle for receptors on phagocytes (eg, Fc receptors, C3b receptors) to grasp. allowing the phagocytes to more easily engulf the foreign cell.
• The importance of C3 is demonstrated by the fact that all 3 complement pathways (lectin, classical and alternative) converge on it. resulting in cleavage into C3a and C3b. C3a helps recruit phagocytic cells and induce inﬂammation. C3b in addition to acting as an opsonin, can bind to C3b convertase and form C5 convertase, ultimately triggering the membrane attack complex.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because she has had a fever for 4 days, has begun vomiting after meals, and is suffering from a severe headache, irritability, and fatigue. Examination shows nuchal rigidity but no rash or conjunctivitis. A cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample is somewhat cloudy and has a white blood cell (WBC) count of 4/Cu.mm with a predominance of lymphocytes. The CSF glucose level is slightly low (60 mg), and the protein level is high (84mg). A Gram slain is negative. An infection with echovirus 11 is suspected. and the child recovers within 8 days without antibiotic treatment. Transmission from person to person of echovirus is facilitated by which viral characteristic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Icosahedral capsid
• As the results of the Gram stain and other laboratory findings suggest the diagnosis of meningitis caused by echovirus 11. This virus is associated with outbreaks of meningitis in children and is transmitted via the fecal-oral route and possibly via aerosols. 
• Like other picornaviruses, echoviruses have a virion capsid that is impervious to the conditions of the gastrointestinal tract and to drying. Echoviruses and other picornaviruses do not have an envelope. 
• Enveloped viruses that may cause meningitis include mumps virus, herpes simplex virus, varicella-zoster virus. HIV, lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus, and some togaviruses and Flaviviruses. 
• Echoviruses do not have hemagglutinin. Hemagglutinins are the attachment proteins for orthomyxoviruses and paramyxoviruses. 
• Echoviruses also do not have NA. NA removes the binding structure (sialic acid) from the virus receptor and is present in orthomyxoviruses and some paramyxoviruses.
• Echoviruses and other picornaviruses are capsid viruses that have a valley into which the cellular virus receptor inserts.
• Enveloped viruses have glycoproteins, but picornaviruses do not.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man seeks evaluation from his family physician with a complaint of  heartburn, which has been gradually increasing over the last 10 years. The heartburn gets worse after eating spicy foods and improves with antacids. The past medical history is benign. He is a security guard and works long hours at night. He admits to smoking 1.5 packs of cigarettes every day. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals several gastric ulcers and regions of inﬂammation. A biopsy is obtained, which revealed the pathogen, as shown in the micrograph below. This organism is associated with gastric adenocarcinoma. Which of the following bacterial products is responsible for neutralizing the acidity of the stomach?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Urease
• This patient has peptic ulcer disease (PUD). In PUD, painful ulcers are present in the stomach and for ﬁrst part of the duodenum. Patients usually present with heartburn that increases with meals [gastric ulcers) or when meals are skipped (duodenal ulcer). 
• Pain is usually relieved by antacids. 
• Helicobacter pylori, a gram-negative bacteria is mainly responsible for these ulcers. H. pylori avoid the acidic environment of the stomach by using its ﬂagella to hide over the mucus lining of the stomach where the pH is more neutral. 
• H. pylori also neutralize the acid by producing large amounts of the enzyme, urease, which hydrolyzes urea to carbon dioxide and ammonia. The ammonia neutralizes stomach acid. 
• Upper GI endoscopy is the recommended diagnostic test for suspected PUD. 
• Endoscopy provides enables the ulcer to be visualized and a biopsy to be obtained when needed to determine the presence and degree of active bleeding and to attempt hemostasis by direct measures.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman makes an appointment with a gynecologist for her ﬁrst  gynecologic examination. She did not disclose her past medical history, but her sexual debut occurred with her boyfriend 3 weeks ago. She is now complaining of a yellow-green, diffuse, malodorous vaginal discharge that she noticed 1 week ago for the ﬁrst time. She also reported mild pelvic and abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness was noted during the pelvic examination. The gynecologist also noticed a pink and inﬂamed nulliparous cervix with a preponderance of small red punctate spots as shown in the image. There was a frothy white discharge with a malodorous odor in the vaginal vault. A wet mount was prepared for a light microscopic examination, which revealed numerous squamous cells and motile organisms. The gynecologist concluded that this was a sexually transmitted infection. What is the Infective stage of this pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Trophozoite
•  A ﬂagellated protozoan parasite, Trichomonas vaginalis, is considered the most frequent non viral sexually transmitted infection worldwide. 
• This obligate human parasite  has only trophozoite stage and survives within the vaginal microflora, epithelial cells  and erythrocytes. 
• Most of the affected patients are asymptomatic; however, within 6 months  approximately one third of infected females develop symptoms, such as vulvar and vaginal itching and irritation, dysuria, and a malodorous diffuse white vaginal discharge. 
• So diagnostic and infective stage is trophozoite.
• A strawberry cervix was visualized during speculum examination. 
• Trichomonas vaginalis is most often diagnosed by light microscopy of a vaginal discharge wet mount microscopy, which reveals the motile protozoan parasite

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with complaints of fever 106.7°F and diarrhea for the past 12 hours. There is no history of  headaches, vomiting, or loss of consciousness. The past medical history is unobtainable due to a language barrier (the patient recently immigrated from Odisha), but his wife says that her husband had a motor vehicle accident when he was a teenager that required surgery. He is transferred to the ICU after a few hours in the ED because of dyspnea, cyanosis, and near collapse. There are no signs of a meningeal infection. The blood pressure was 70/30 mm Hg at the time of transfer. A chest X—ray at the time of admission showed interstitial inﬁltrates without homogeneous opacities. The initial laboratory results reveal metabolic acidosis, leukopenia with a count of 2,000/mm3, thrombocytopenia (15,000/mm3), and a coagulation proﬁle suggestive of disseminated coagulation. A peripheral smear was performed and is shown image. Despite ventilatory support. administration of intravenous fluids, antibiotics, and vasopressor agents, the patient died the next day. A Gram stain from an autopsy specimen of the lungs revealed gram-positive, Iancet-shaped diplococci occurring singly or in chains. How this infection could be prevented?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Administration of PPV23

• This patient most likely died due to an overwhelming infection with Streptococcus pneumoniae that led to septicemia and septic shock. 
• The peripheral smear shows Howell—Jolly bodies, which are basophilic remnants . within the circulating erythrocytes that are normally removed by the spleen in healthy individuals. The presence of Howell-Jolly bodies signiﬁes a nonfunctional or absent spleen. 
• Together, the history of a motor vehicle accident and the peripheral blood picture are highly suggestive that he is asplenic. Blunt abdominal trauma during a motor vehicle accident can lead to splenic rupture requiring a splenectomy. Asplenic patients are known to be at an increased risk of contracting fulminant Iife threatening infections by encapsulated organisms, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Hemophilus influenzae type B, and Neisseria meningitidis.
• The polysaccharide capsule in these organisms has anti-phagocytic properties. The spleen acts as a major lymphoid organ for the eradication of extracellular encapsulated bacteria via opsonization. Proper immunization with PPV 23 and antibiotic prophylaxis in asplenic patients will prevent this complication.

questions.text: A 2 year-old boy is brought to a clinic with intermittent fevers and a rash for 6 days. According to his mother, he is also complaining of pain all over his body. She adds that the rash ﬁrst appeared on his face within 12 hours of the onset of fever, and later spread to his trunks and limbs. The patient denies any itchiness over the rash. There is no history of a sore throat or recent use of medication for symptom relief. His temperature is 37.2°C and the pulse is 88/min. On examination. there is a maculopapular rash on the face and the trunk, including the limbs, but sparing the palms and soles. The pediatrician reassures the mother that this is most likely a viral infection and will resolve spontaneously. After 7—10 days, the boy is brought back to the clinic for a follow-up visit. The areas affected by the rash appear to have a central clearing giving a lacy or reticular appearance as shown in the image. lgM antibody detection by ELISA will most likely detect antibodies against which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Parvovirus B19

• Fifth disease is caused by a single-stranded DNA virus (parvovirus B19). The virus replicates in erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow and fetal liver. 
• Parvo virus B19 is transmitted through airborne droplets. The incubation period of the Fifth disease is 7—10 days and most commonly occurs in children 6—14 years of age; however, younger children can also be infected. 
• The majority of infections are asymptomatic or exhibit mild. non-specific., cold-like symptoms. 
• The typical presentation includes a prodrome consisting of mild fevers with a sore throat, coryza, headaches, and gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea and vomiting). 
• During the initial stage. erythema of the cheeks is present. After 1—4 days, a maculopapular rash occurs on the extremities and trunk in a lacy, reticular pattern caused by the central clearing of the rash. 
• The rash usually resolves within 7-10 days. 
• Patients will be positive for Parvo B19 IgM ELISA.

choices.text: Hemolytic black colonies in blood agar
Bluish green colonies on Loefﬂer's serum
Metallic green colonies on eosin-methylene blue agar

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy presents with a sore throat. fever, chills, and difﬁculty swallowing 6 for the past 3 days. The patient's mother says that last night he was short of breath and had a headache. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient has not  been vaccinated as his mother thinks it is "unnecessary". His temperature is 101.0°F, blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. pulse is 110/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. On physical examination, the patient is ill-appearing and dehydrated. There are a grayish-white membrane and pharyngeal erythema present in the oropharynx.  Signiﬁcant cervical lymphadenopathy is present. A throat swab is taken, and gram  stain shows gram-positive, club-shaped bacilli along with few neutrophils. Which of  the following would most likely be the result of the bacterial culture of the throat  swab in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Greyish-white colonies on Thayer-Martin agar
• Given the symptoms and the physical examination ﬁndings of cervical lymphadenopathy and greyish-white membrane in the oropharynx, this patient most likely has diphtheria. 
• Diphtheria is caused by a non-motile. non-encapsulated, club-shaped, gram-positive bacillus, Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 
• It is further classiﬁed (mitts, intermedius, and gravis) according to the colony morphology and bacteriophage sensitivity. 
• Conﬁrmation of the diagnosis depends upon culture results showing the growth of toxigenic C. diphtheriae
• For primary isolation of this organism, a variety of culture media can be used: Loeffler agar, Mueller-Miller tellurite agar or Tinsdale tellurite agar. 
• Blood agar may reveal small, greyish, smooth. non-hemolytic colonies. The tellurite agar growth shows small black colonies with a black halo while Loeffler's serum shows white-greyish colonies

questions.text: A 75-year-old man who underwent a bilateral lung transplant 11 months ago presented to the emergency room with fevers and chills. After the transplant procedure, he was immediately placed on immunosuppressive treatment; however, for unknown reasons he stopped taking the prophylactically prescribed voriconazole. Upon presentation to the emergency room. the patient was hypoxemic. Imaging revealed pulmonary nodules, which prompted a transbronchial biopsy for further evaluation. The results were negative for acute organ rejection, adenovirus, cytomegalovirus, and acid-fast bacilli. Slides stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) revealed the pathogen. The specimen was sent to the microbiology laboratory for fungal culture, which resulted in the growth of a fuzzy mold on Sabouraud agar at 250C. A Lactophenol cotton blue preparation revealed the organism shown in the image. What organism has infected this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Coccidioides species
• Coccidioides species (most notably, Coccidioides immitis and Coccidioides posadasii) are dimorphic fungi that are endemic for not and dry areas of the southwestern United States and northern parts of Mexico. 
• The incidence of infection with this pathogen is increasing, and the spectrum of illnesses caused by Coccidioides species is very broad. No known colonization state exists for this fungus. 
• Although the morphology of Coccidioides may vary substantially in the tissues. large thick-walled round structures [spherules] packed with endospores are the  classical presentation, which may be identiﬁed using H&E, GMS, PAS, Papanicoulou, and calcoﬂuor stains.  A granulomatous reaction around the spherules is often an accompanying ﬁnding. 
• The fungus can also grow like mold on solid media, revealing thin hyphae and speciﬁc barrel-  shaped arthroconidia on a lactophenol cotton blue preparation.

questions.text: A 29-year-old internal medicine resident reports to the emergency department with  complaints of fevers, diarrhea. abdominal pain, and skin rash for 2 days. He feels  fatigued and has lost his appetite. On further questioning, he says that he returned from his missionary trip to Brazil last week. He is excited as he talks about his trip.  Besides a worthy clinical experience, he also enjoyed local outdoor activities, like  swimming and rafting. His past medical history is insigniﬁcant. The blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, the pulse is 100lmin, and the temperature is 38.3°C. On  examination, there is a rash on the legs. The rest of the examination is normal.  Stool examination revealed the pathogen as shown in the image, Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's a condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Schistosoma mansoni
• Schistosomiasis is a tropical disease that occurs following an Schistosomiasis infection with parasitic worms (ﬂukes) known as schistosomes. 
• Schistosomiasis is also called snail fever. These worms are endemic to Africa, South America, the Caribbean, the Middle East, and Asia. 
• Schistosomes are parasites that inhabit freshwater snails. 
• Different types of snails act as hosts of the genus Schistosoma. 
• Complications arise due to immunologic reactions toward trapped eggs of schistosomes in various tissues. 
• The eggs reach the skin. brain, muscles, adrenal glands, and eyes. Eventually, the excessive inﬂammatory process causes organ damage.
• Egg morphology suggestive of S. mansoni – Egg with lateral spine.

questions.text: Match the age group for measles vaccination under different strategies:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A – II; B – I; C – II
WHO Measles elimination strategy
Supplementation Immunization Service (Target: > 90%)
• Catch up – Nationwide vaccination campaign, targeting all children 9 months to 15 years (both India & WHO), irrespective of history of measles disease or vaccination status
• Keep up – Routine vaccination aimed at vaccinating each birth cohort
• Follow up – Subsequent nationwide vaccination campaign conducted every 2 – 4 years wherein all children born after catch up phase are given vaccine

questions.text: A previously healthy 32 years old female presented with rotatory vertigo associated with nausea and vomiting. The symptoms had started five days earlier as short lasting vertigo attacks, her symptoms had been continuous for three days. Clinical examination showed BP 200/95. Otoscopy was normal No nystagmus in a neutral position, and no pathological findings by standard clinical neurological examination was found. The next day the patient was still nauseated and described continuous vertigo, with a slight improvement. Hallpikes manoeuvre did not evoke nystagmus or exacerbation of her vertigo. Identify the investigation being done in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Vestibular Evoked Myogenic potential.
Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
• In VEMP, we stimulate the saccule with sound and we record the contractions of Sternocleidomastoid muscle ( Vestibulocollic reflex). 
• This test checks the inferior vestibular division of 8th nerve as saccule is supplied by this nerve.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic consults a physician because of severe and persistent earache. Otoscopic examination demonstrates foul-smelling purulent otorrhea and a red mass lesion of the external ear canal. Biopsy of the mass demonstrates granulation tissue rather than tumor. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pseudomonas aeruginosa 
Sol:

• External otitis, or infection of the external ear canal, can be caused by a variety of organisms, notably including Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Proteus vulgaris, and Staphylococcus aureus. There is, however, a severe subtype of external otitis, malignant external otitis, of which you should be aware. This form is specifically caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and tends to affect elderly diabetics and AIDS patients, causing the findings illustrated in the question stem. It is particularly worrisome both because the Pseudomonas organism is so tissue destructive and because it is often highly resistant to most intravenous antibiotics. (Consult your local microbiology or pharmacology departments for advice about local sensitivities if you encounter the condition.) Complications can be devastating, including deafness, facial nerve paralysis, osteomyelitis, and meningitis. 
• Escherichia coli can cause both external otitis and acute otitis media, but does not usually cause malignant external otitis. 
• Haemophilus influenza is an important cause of acute otitis media. 
Proteus vulgaris can cause external otitis, but does not usually cause the malignant form.

questions.text: 21 yrs old male patient with a one year history of development of nasal obstruction on the left with intermittent epistaxis in several opportunities, the latest episode of two days, accompanied by clear rhinorrhea, progressive decrease in olfaction, intermittent bilateral hearing loss at three months of development and weight loss of approximately 10 kg in one year. One examination palpation one lymph node of size 3 cm* 2cm at level III. On oral cavity examination palatal palsy was suspected. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
Ref: Read the text below
Sol.
• Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) is a relatively uncommon cancer with an incidence of 0.29 per 100,000 people per year in Japan. 
• However, there are certain populations in whom the incidence is considerably higher, including native and foreign-born Chinese, Southeast Asians, North Africans, and native people of the Arctic region.
• Classification of the World Health Organization divides NPC on a pathological basis into three histological subtypes: keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma; nonkeratinizing carcinoma, which can be further divided into differentiated and undifferentiated subtypes; and basaloid squamous cell carcinoma. Undifferentiated nonkeratinizing NPC is the most common type of NPC and is strongly associated with the Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) in practically 100% of cases. 
• The most common site of origin for NPC is the lateral wall of the nasopharynx, especially the fossa of Rosenmüller, followed by the superior posterior wall. Nearly half of patients complain of nasal symptoms. 
• Symptoms related to Eustachian tube obstruction, such as serous otitis media, also commonly occur. Headache and cranial nerve involvement are features of more advanced stages. A direct lateral spread of NPC involves the third division of the trigeminal nerve (V3). The perineural spread of the V3 is one of the most common and important routes in the intracranial paracavernous extension of NPC [3].
• Gadolinium-enhanced, fat-suppressed, T1-weighted MR imaging is very useful in detecting perineural tumor invasion and extracranial lesions

questions.text:
A 27-year-old female presented to the Otolaryngology department with a mass in the left nasal cavity. Her chief complaint was persistent nasal congestion with intermittent epistaxis over the past 5 years. Three years earlier she had been treated for suspected allergic or chronic rhinitis without resolution of symptoms.

A nasal exam was performed using rigid endoscopy, which revealed a large mass, medial to the middle turbinate in the left nasal cavity. The mass extended to the choana, but did not appear to extend into the nasopharynx clinically.It was attached superiorly.The lesion was pink and lobulated with a rubbery, non-friable texture.Study Coronal CT and sagittal MRI and comment on the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Olfactory neuroblastoma

Ref: Read the text below

Sol.

Olfactory neuroblastoma arise from the specialized sensory neuroepithelial (neuroectodermal) olfactory cells that are normally found in the upper part of the nasal cavity, including the superior nasal concha, the upper part of septum, the roof of nose, and the cribriform plate of ethmoid.

ONB may occur at any age, but a bimodal age distribution in the 2nd and 6th decades of life are most common without a gender predilection.

The tumors most commonly cause unilateral nasal obstruction (70%), and epistaxis (50%), while less common signs and symptoms include headaches, pain, excessive lacrimation, rhinorrhea, anosmia, and visual disturbances.

Even though the tumor arises from the olfactory neuroepithelium, anosmia is not a common complaint (5%). Due to the non-specific nature of the initial presentation and slow growth of the tumors, patients often have a long history before diagnosis.

 

There are isolated cases reports of ONB secreting vasopressin with resultant hypertension and hyponatremia.

A “dumbbell-shaped” mass extending across the cribriform plate is one of the most characteristic imaging findings for this tumor. 

                   

Coronal CT and sagittal MRI

(A) Coronal CT scan shows a mass in the left nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, and frontal lobe with destruction of the cribriform plate and medial orbital wall. There is vasogenic edema and subfalcine herniation. (B) T1-weighted contrast-enhanced MRI shows a dumbbell-shaped enhancing mass in the left frontal lobe, the nasal cavity, and the sphenoid sinus.

 

Complete surgical elimination frequently requires a bicranial-facial approach (trephination) which removes the cribriform plate, and is usually followed by a course of radiotherapy as the treatment of choice to achieve the best long term outcome. 

 

  • PITUITARY MACROADENOMA
    • Epicentre more posteriorly located
  • JUVENILE NASOPHARYNGEAL ANGIOFIBROMA
    • Epicentre more posteroinferiorly located
    • Almost exclusively in males
    • Often somewhat younger

questions.text: A 70-year-old obese woman was seen in OPD with an 8-week history of clear discharge from her left nostril which was worse on exertion. She reported that the nasal discharge was associated with a headache without fever.  She had a similar episode of left rhinorrhea 4 months ago, which lasted about 4 weeks; it was self-limiting and resolved without surgical intervention. There was a past history of trauma 1 yr back On physical examination, no other abnormalities were noted ,what would be the next step:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Electrophoretic analysis
Ref: Read the text below
Sol.
• Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhoea is usually secondary to severe head trauma. Spontaneous CSF leak is an infrequent entity and represents only 4% of CSF rhinorrhoea cases.
• Electrophoretic analysis of the nasal discharge was positive for Tau protein (β2-transferrin), which is specific to CSF, establishing a diagnosis of CSF rhinorrhoea. A CT cisternogram located the site of the defect (fistula) to the left cribriform plate.
• The patient underwent an endoscopic endonasal fistula repair under general anaesthesia and made an uncomplicated recovery. She was symptom-free when followed up 1 month postoperative.

questions.text: The COVID-19 is part of the species of the SARS-related coronaviruses  is presented mainly by lower respiratory tract related symptoms such as fever, cough, dyspnea and chest tightness that could progress rapidly to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) .Most common ENT manifestations of COVID-19 is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sore Throat 
Ref: Read the text below
Sol.
• The COVID-19 is part of the species of the SARS-related coronaviruses  is presented mainly by lower respiratory tract related symptoms such as fever, cough, dyspnea and chest tightness that could progress rapidly to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) . 
• However, COVID-19 causes also different upper respiratory tract related symptoms including nasal congestion, sore throat and smell dysfunction .
• The available data on the ear nose throat (ENT) manifestations of COVID-19 is sparsely published and out of the best of our knowledge, no previous review study to collect and describe the ORL manifestation in COVID-19 positive patients. 
• Thus, the aim of the current work was to detect and discuss the different otorhinolaryngology (ORL) manifestations those were reported in COVID-19 positive patients in the reviewed and published literatures.

questions.text: A 23 year old male patient came to the ENT OPD with chief complaint of mass lesion involving the upper lip and bilateral nostrils leading to progressive nasal obstruction and impaired sense of smell for past 2 years (Fig). He observed an ulcerated nodular lesion in his palate causing difficulty in eating and swallowing since last one year. To start with he noticed a small mass in the right nostril which gradually progressed to fill not only bilateral nostrils but also extended to involve the vestibule crossing the midline over the collumela and adjacent part of the upper lip. The lesion was painful on touch with occasional episodes of unprovoked bleeding. He is a day labourer by profession, drank socially, but never smoked.Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rhinoscleroma
Ref: Read the text below
Sol.
Rhinoscleroma:
Definition: Chronic, progressive granulomatous infection of nose and upper lip area. This can also involve  larynx ( scleroma Larynx)
Organism: Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Gram negative: Frisch Bacillus).
It is more common in northern part of India
Clinical Picture:
1.Atrophic Stage 
Atrophic changes occur in the floor of the nose, septum and turbinates
2. Granulomatous Stage:
 Subdermal infiltration of the lower part of the external nose and the upper lip (woody feel)
3. Cicatrical Stage:    in this stage due to fibrosis, patient develops cosmetic deformity
Diagnosis:                                                                                                
Submucosal infiltration of plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells & Russel bodies                   
Mikulicz Cells:                                                                                                   
Large foam cells with a central nucleus & vacuolated cytoplasm (contain the bacilli)
Russell Bodies:
Eccentric nucleus and a pink- staining cytoplasm- Look like plasma cells.
Treatment:
1. Streptomycin (2 gm/day) 
2. Tetracyline (2 gm/day)

choices.text: Switch to bipolar TURP equipment and finish the case.

questions.text: In the course of performing a monopolar TURP under spinal block,thenurse anesthetist reports the patient is suddenly markedlyconfused, brachycardic, and hypertensive. An emergent serumsodium level is 110 mEq/L. The following are the next best steps:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Drop the height of the irrigating fluid to <60 cm above the patient, control bleeding, terminate the case, administer
furosemide, and begin a calculated dose of hypertonic saline. Patient is likely experiencing TUR syndrome; thus rapid
termination is needed. The height of the irrigating fluid above the patient should be carefully chosen. Investigators have demonstrated that the ideal height of the fluid was 60 cm above the patient. This appears to be the minimal height to maintain good vision but also not lead to excessive systemic fluid absorption. Increasing the height 10 cm above this leads to increased pressure in the prostatic fossa and a greater than twofold increase in systemic fluid absorption. Diagnosis of this condition is made by assessment of neurologic status and comparison to laboratory values. Serum sodium should be obtained in long, large resections postoperatively (or intraoperatively if concern exists). A serum sodium of less than 120 mEq/L indicates a significant dilution and may lead to coma or seizures. Transient visual disturbances or blindness indicate central
nervous system (CNS) toxicity and are obviously very distressing to all the parties involved. If profound central nervous symptoms are noted, judicious administration of hypertonic saline should be instituted and formulas exist to help guide this resuscitation as overly rapid correction of hyponatremia may lead to a demyelinating lesion of the brain (central pontine myelinolysis).

choices.text: Prostatic urethral calculus is always migratory

questions.text: All are true about prostatic calculi except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prostatic calculi can be either prostatic urethral calculus or true prostatic calculi (within the prostate). Prostatic urethral calculus is always migratory and should be managed as any other urethral calculi. True prostatic calculi can be either primary/endogenous (occurring within the acini of the prostate) or secondary/exogenous (reflux of urine into the prostate). The majority of prostatic calculi are composed of calcium phosphate (83%).

questions.text: A patient presents to the surgical emergency after a road traffic accident. He underwent damage control surgery. On post op day 5 he develops hypoalbuminemia. What is the cause of this drop in albumin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increaed microvascular permeability rather than decreased production is responsible for the hypoalbuminemia.
Hypoalbuminemia is a common and vexing postoperative complication. In some case series, about 20% to 40% of patients sustained an acute, prolonged, and profound drop in serum albumin after elective surgery
The laws of physiology suggest that hypoalbuminemia reflects some combination of decreased albumin production, increased losses, acute dilution or shifts from the vascular space.5 Low production is easy to hypothesize in a patient with anorexia. However, the half-life of albumin is about 3 weeks.6 Hence, total starvation with zero production would not explain rapid-onset hypoalbuminemia. Acute dilution could be rapid, yet it seems implausible in patients who have a normal hemoglobin and uric acid level after surgery.
One popular explanation relates to displacement into an extravascular space
Capillary leak is defined as an excessive loss of fluid and protein into the interstitial space as a result of endothelial cell dysfunction. This is one of the most widely studied and clinically apparent consequences of ischemia-reperfusion vessel injury and other acute inflammatory reactions. Both apoptosis and necrosis of endothelial cells may contribute to capillary leak, as well as the inflammatory mediators released from activated neutrophils such as tumour necrosis factor alpha and interleukin beta

questions.text: A patient presents with a hyperpigmented lesion on the back with irregular border. Which of the following drugs has been approved by the FDA as an adjuvant therapy for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The  systemic adjuvant therapy approved by the U.S. FDA is high dose interferon alpha 2b.
Chemotherapy agents used for adjuvant treatment of melanoma include dacarbazine, cisplatin, and vinblastine. Nivolumab, ipilimumab, or interferon (IFN) alfa-2b are options for adjuvant therapy approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for high-risk resected melanoma, defined as deep primaries greater than 4 mm in Breslow depth (American Joint Committee on Cancer [AJCC] stage IIB) and regional lymph node metastasis (stage III). IFN is given in high doses, as trials of low-dose IFN have shown no benefit in disease-free relapse or overall survival (OS) rates.  Nivolumab and pembrolizumab are options for adjuvant therapy of resected advanced melanoma.
Dabrafenib plus trametinib is also a useful combination for BRAF V600E or V600K mutation–positive unresectable or metastatic melanoma. Additionally, it is approved for adjuvant therapy in combination with trametinib for melanoma with BRAF V600E or V600K mutations and involvement of lymph node(s), following complete resection

questions.text: A 56-year-old male undergoes radical parotidectomy. Which of the following is not true regarding nerve injuries post radical parotidectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Radical parotidectomy is performed for patients in whom there is clear histological evidence of a high-grade malignant tumour (e.g. squamous cell carcinoma) with invasion of facial nerve. Low-grade and low stage malignant tumours can usually be managed by standard superficial parotidectomy. Radical parotidectomy involves removal of all parotid gland tissue and elective division of the facial nerve, usually through the main trunk.
Facial nerve, greater auricular nerve and auriculotemporal nerve are at risk of injury during parotid surgery.

questions.text: A 25 yr old male after road traffic accident was diagnosed as grade 4 splenic injury and splenectomy was done as he was hemodynamically unstable. In the post op period patient left hospital against medical advice and he didn’t recive vaccine. The risk of OPSI (overwhelming post splenectomy infections) is maximum at?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Older studies have shown that the risk is greatest within the first 2 years after splenectomy, but recent studies have confirmed that a lifelong risk remains. One third of cases occur more than 5 years after surgery, with the overall incidence reported to be 3.2% to 3.5%. For those who acquire OPSI, mortality is between 40% and 50%.3 The risk is greatest in patients with thalassemia major and sickle cell disease. OPSI is typically caused by polysaccharide-encapsulated organisms, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus influenzae.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed as acute appendicitis and during appendectomy a mucinous appendiceal tumour was found, despite adequate care tumour got ruptured during surgery. Later patient presented with abdominal pain and it was diagnosed as Pseudomyxoma peritoni. Treatment of pseudomyxoma peritonei involves
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The current treatment of patients with pseudomyxoma peritonei involves resection of as much of the tumor as possible (cytoreduction) and intraperitoneal heated chemotherapy (HIPEC). Operative management includes omentectomy, stripping of involved peritoneum, resection of involved organs, and appendectomy, if not previously performed. There should be no residual tumor nodules larger than 2 mm in diameter after resection to facilitate penetration of the chemotherapy into any residual disease. In general, a right hemicolectomy is performed for these tumors.

questions.text: ‘Bear-Claw’ appearance on CECT abdomen is seen in:

CT is currently the diagnostic modality of choice for the evaluation of blunt liver trauma in hemodynamically stable patients . 

CT can help accurately diagnose parenchymal injuries and exclude surgical lesions such as bowel or pancreatic injuries.

Lacerations commonly parallel the hepatic or portal venous vasculature and often extend to the periphery of the liver. They may have a configuration that has been termed the bear claw pattern due to its radiating, parallel, and jagged appearance.

questions.text: A patient with portal hypertension presented with hemetemesis due to variceal bleed, the bleed was controlled by endoscopic banding and on further evaluation patient was advised for liver transplantation. The shunts are inserted under local anaesthetic, analgesia and sedation, using fluoroscopic guidance and ultrasonography. Via the internal jugular vein and SVC, a guidewire is inserted into a hepatic vein and through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein.

questions.text: At her follow-up visit after her MRM(modified radical mastectomy) operation, the patient reports feeling a sensation of numbness in her upper inner arm. She has full motor strength of the extremity, and the remainder of her arm has normal sensation. Her incisions appear to be healing well. What is the most likely etiology of this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Injury to the intercostobrachial nerve, the lateral cutaneous branch of the second intercostal nerve, results in numbness of the medial upper arm.
Traditional modified radical mastectomy focuses on protecting the long thoracic nerve and thoracodorsal nerve while ignoring the protection of the anterior thoracic nerve and intercostobrachial nerve protection, which leads often to patients with upper medial arm .
The intercostobrachial nerve passes through the intercostal muscle in the 2nd intercostal space behind the outer margin of the pectoralis minor, passes through the axillary fat pad, crosses the anterior margin of the latissimus dorsi muscle, and runs laterally. Its trunk is parallel to the axillary vein . In surgery, as long as we are familiar with these anatomical structures, there will be no difficulty in protecting them mbness, arm swelling, pain, chest atrophy, and other problems

questions.text: A 30 yr old female comes to the breast clinic as she is worried because her sister recently diagnosed with breast cancer and she wants to know what are her chances of getting breast cancer in future.  All of the following are part of the Gail model calculation of 5-year and lifetime breast cancer risk except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The Gail model is a statistical model based on data from the Breast Cancer Detection Demonstration Project, a mammography screening program conducted in the 1970s. The model incorporates race, age, age at first menses, age at first live birth, number of first-degree relatives with breast cancer, and number of previous biopsies, including benign results and those with atypical hyperplasia. The program derives 5-year and lifetime risks for breast cancer by multi- plying relative risks from several categories.

A risk greater than 1.7% at 5 years deserves further addressing, and the patient should be appropriately counseled regarding her increased risk. Tamoxifen has now been shown to decrease the 5-year and lifetime risks in these patients by almost 50%. This is based on the NSABP-P1 study data. Further studies are ongoing to examine the role of other estrogen-blocking drugs, such as raloxifene
