questions.text: A 50 year old male with medical history of type 2 diabetes for 8 years presented to you in OPD.  He has no other previous medical history. But he is concerned about his kidneys as there is family history of chronic kidney disease in father which needed dialysis and ultimately renal transplant. He is asymptomatic otherwise. BP-126/80 mmHg, No other abnormality detected on physical examination. Which test will be useful for him to assess diabetes nephropathy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Urine for microalbumin

 Microalbuminuria is defined as 30-300 mg/d in a 24-h collection or 30-300 micro g/mg creatinine in a spot collection (preferred method). 

 In patients with types 1 or 2 diabetes, microalbuminuria appears 5-10 years after the onset of diabetes and is useful in detecting diabetes nephropathy even before serum creatinine or BUN are elevated.

questions.text: A 60 year old man presented with complaint of puffiness of face more in morning and decreases as day progresses for last 2 months.He also complaints of frothy urine.On examination facial swelling present,per abdomen- hepatosplenomegaly present.Lab results showed proteinuria of 8 g/d.Renal biopsy done which showed features of amyloidosis.All of the following can be the cause of his Amyloidosis  except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Enteric fever  

Secondary (reactive) systemic amyloidosis: 
 Protein type – AA type 
 Organs commonly involved – liver, spleen, kidney, adrenals.
 Causes – chronic infections (Suppurative), tuberculosis, bronchiectasis, chronic osteomyelitis, chronic pyelonephritis, leprosy, autoimmune disorders (RA, dermatomyositis, scleroderma) inflammatory bowel disease (ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease), some tumours (renal cell carcinoma, Hodgkin’s disease).

questions.text: A 25 year old female presented with features suggestive of chronic inflammatory diarrhea. On further evaluation with colonic biopsy diagnosis of ulcerative colitis was made. She will have which extra intestinal manifestation more common as compared with Crohn’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pyoderma Gangreosum 
Extraintestinal manifestations more common with CD than UC are- 
•	Nephrolithiasis  (ca oxalate) 
•	Hepatic steatosis
•	Ankylosing Spondylitis 
•	Gall stones  
•	Erythema  nodosum

Extraintestinal manifestations which parallel Bowel disease activity
1. Erythema Nodosum
2. Episcleritis
3. Gall stones
4.  Peripheral arthritis 
5. renal stones

Extraintestinal   manifestations which occurs independent of bowel disease activity 
1. PSC 
2. Ankylosing spondylitis
3. UVEITIS 
4. Pyoderma gangrenosum
Smoking is protective against UC & Worsens CD

choices.text: Pulmonary plethora and pulmonary atresia with intact ventricular septum.
Prominent right heart border and ASD.

questions.text: Which of the following associations is recognized
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prominent right heart border and ASD.  

In pulmonary atresia with intact ventricular septum there is decreased pulmonary blood flow.
The prominent right heart border occurs in ASD because of right atrial hypertrophy. 
In endocardial fibroelastosis the interior of the ventricles appears echogenic, but there is no pericardial calcification. Pericardial calcification is found in constrictive pericarditis. 
A 'cottage loaf' heart is characteristic of TAPVD.

choices.text: Empiric trial of prednisone 15 mg daily

questions.text:
A previously healthy and active 72-year-old woman presents to your office with a complaint of stiffness and pain in her neck and shoulders. The symptoms are much worse in the morning and improve throughout the day. The pain affects the soft tissues and does not appear localized to the shoulder or hip joints. She denies headache or jaw claudication. Physical examination is unrevealing; there is no inflammatory synovitis, muscle tenderness, or skin rash. Muscle strength is normal in the deltoid and iliopsoas muscle groups. She has normal range of motion of the shoulder and hip joints.
Laboratory studies reveal an elevated ESR of 92 mm/h and a mild normocytic anemia. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Empiric trial of prednisone 15 mg daily

The patient has polymyalgia rheumatica. A relatively common disease of the elderly, PMR presents as morning stiffness and pain in the shoulders, neck, and hip girdle. Diagnosis is mainly clinical; improvement of symptoms throughout the day and an absence of joint findings on physical examination provide clues to the diagnosis. Most patients have a markedly elevated ESR. PMR overlaps with giant cell (temporal) arteritis, so it is worthwhile to ask about symptoms of headache or jaw claudication. In the absence of symptoms or signs of temporal arteritis, no additional testing is indicated, and the diagnosis is presumptively confirmed by prompt response to moderate dose steroids (10-20 mg prednisone per day).
A graded exercise regimen (answer b) would be an appropriate treatment option for fibromyalgia, but fibromyalgia rarely begins at age 72 and does not cause elevation of the ESR. MRI of the upper torso may show inflammation of the bursa and shoulder joint synovium, but this patient does not have localized tenderness in these structures.
Temporal artery biopsy should be performed in patients suspected of having giant cell arteritis. Our patient, however, denies symptoms consistent with arterial involvement. If the patient does not respond to treatment with steroids, stronger consideration should be given to temporal artery biopsy.

choices.text: Treat with antibiotics and observe on the general medicine ward for 24 hours

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with chronic obstructive lung disease requires 2 L/min of nasal O2 to treat his hypoxia, which is sometimes associated with angina. The patient develops pleuritic chest pain, fever, and purulent sputum. While using his oxygen at an increased flow of 5 L/min, he becomes stuporous and develops a respiratory acidosis with CO2 retention and worsening hypoxia. What would be the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Intubate and begin mechanical ventilation

This patient presents with severe COPD and hypoxemia. Chronic CO2 retention has blunted his hypercarbic drive to breathe; he is dependent on mild hypoxia to stimulate respiration. Delivery of high oxygen concentration has decreased his hypoxic drive
Of the choices listed, the initiation of mechanical ventilation is the only acceptable choice. If the patient’s mental status were better, non invasive ventilation (BiPAP) might be considered. Medroxyprogesterone has only a mild stimulatory effect on the respiratory center, and is not appropriate therapy in this case. Antibiotics and inhaled bronchodilators are appropriate
 reatments for COPD exacerbation but would not manage this patient’s acute hypercarbic respiratory failure.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman presents with 6 weeks of fatigue, dyspnea, and night sweats. She has lost 5 kg weight. She has no history of trauma, has never had surgery, and takes no medications. Chest x-ray reveals a large right-sided pleural effusion. Thoracentesis yields pleural fluid that appears milky.
Pleural fluid triglyceride level is 500 mg/dL. Which of the following disorders is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lymphoma

This patient has a chylothorax. In chylothorax, the pleural fluid appears milky and has a triglyceride level over 110 mg/dL. Chylothorax occurs when chyle accumulates in the pleural space due to disruption of the thoracic duct. This is most often due to traumatic or surgical injury to the thoracic duct. In this patient without trauma or recent surgery, a mediastinal tumor (such as lymphoma) would be most likely. Chylous pleural effusions are usually exudative. Pulmonary embolism, systemic lupus, and pneumonia may all be associated with pleural effusions, but pleural effusions associated with these conditions are not Chylous.

choices.text: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis due to thermophilic actinomycetes

questions.text: A 62-year-old automobile service worker presents with gradually worsening exertional dyspnea over the preceding several months. Recently, he has noticed right pleuritic chest pain. He has hypertension, well controlled on amlodipine 5 mg/d. He takes no other medications. He has never noticed cough or wheezing while at work. He worked for 15 years in construction and demolition and for 20 years thereafter in the service department of an automotive dealership. He denies fever, chills, or night sweats. On physical examination, he is in no respiratory distress but has right basilar dullness. His finger oximetry reads 96% on room air. Chest x-ray reveals a moderate right pleural effusion and lateral pleural thickening on both sides. Thoracentesis shows reddish fluid, which on formal analysis is an exudate with 45,000 RBCs/hpf. Cytology is negative. What is the most likely explanation for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Asbestos exposure
Exposure to asbestos in demolition, automobile servicing, or ship building industries is suggestive of asbestos-related disease; bilateral pleural thickening (often calcified, a finding especially evident on CT scan) indicates prior asbestos exposure. Occasionally, the pleural involvement is associated with a pleural effusion (often with an elevated red cell count) called benign asbestos pleural effusion (BAPE). “Benign” distinguishes this syndrome from malignant effusions due to lung cancer or mesothelioma, both of which occur with increased frequency in asbestosis. 
Medications, especially nitrofurantoin and cancer chemotherapeutic agents, can cause interstitial lung disease, but amlodipine has not been reported to do so. Tuberculosis occurs with increased frequency in silicosis, not in asbestosis. Although TB can cause a bloody pleural effusion, this patient does not have the systemic symptoms that usually accompany TB. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an important cause of occupational lung disease, but it is caused by exposure to organic materials such as thermophilic actinomycetes (farmer’s lung). In addition, hypersensitivity pneumonitis usually causes acute symptoms (including fever) at time of exposure. Occupational asthma is an important category, since continued exposure can lead to irreversible changes. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis and occupational asthma do not cause pleural disease.

choices.text: This is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presented with fatigue and dyspnea on exertion 1 month after her second vaginal delivery. Physical examination reveals a laterally displaced apical impulse, elevated jugular venous pressure, and pitting lower extremity edema. Echocardiogram shows systolic dysfunction with an ejection fraction of 30%. Which statement most accurately describes her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy

Peripartum cardiomyopathy may occur during the last trimester of pregnancy or within 6 months of delivery, it most commonly develops in the month before or after delivery. The most common demographics are multiparity and age greater than 30. These women should avoid future pregnancies because peripartum cardiomyopathy often recurs with subsequent pregnancies.
Treatment is the same as for other dilated cardiomyopathies. Beta-blockers, digoxin, and diuretics can be used cautiously during pregnancy; ACE inhibitors should be started after delivery. Diagnosis can typically be made without invasive testing.

questions.text: An otherwise asymptomatic 65-year-old man with diabetes presents to the ER with a sports related right shoulder injury. His heart rate is noted to be irregular, and ECG is obtained (shown in the following figure). Which of the following is the best immediate therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Observation

This ECG shows Wenckebach second-degree AV block (ie, progressive PR interval prolongation before the blocked atrial impulse). This rhythm generally does not require therapy. It may be seen in normal individuals, especially with increased vagal tone due to pain or nausea. Other causes of Wenckebach phenomenon include inferior MI and drug intoxications from digoxin, betablockers, or calcium-channel blockers. Even in the post-MI setting, Wenckebach second-degree AV block is usually stable

choices.text: An 8-mm vegetation is already indication for surgery

questions.text: A 50 year old man with known case of rheumatic hear disease with mitral stenosis and mitral regurgitation developed fever for 3 weeks.He is complaining of palpitations and increasing dyspnea since then.On examination there are osler nodes,conjunctival petechie and Janeway lesion.Cardiac examination revealed LV S3,both pansystolic and middiastolic murmur at apex.Respiratory examination revealed bilateral crepts.ECHO showed oscillating mass lesion on mitral valve.Which of the following is an indication for surgical therapy in the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The development of pulmonary edema
The clinical features are suggestive of infective endocarditis.The main indications of surgery in IE are-
(1) development of significant HF 
(2) persistent bacteraemia despite appropriate treatment; and 
(3) presence or high risk of embolization while on medical therapy

choices.text: Basilar rales halfway up both posterior lung fields

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman was recently diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus. She presents with progressive dyspnea and chest pain for 2 weeks. Jugular venous distension is present and heart sounds are muffled. ECG shows electrical alternans. Chest x-ray is shown in the following figure.

Which of the following is the most likely additional physical finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Pulsus paradoxus

In cardiac tamponade pericardial fluid impedes diastolic filling, resulting in reduced cardiac output and hypotension. ECG may show electric alternans due to the heart sloshing around in the pericardial sac. Typical physical examination findings in cardiac tamponade include elevation of jugular venous pressure and pulsus paradoxus. In contrast to pulmonary edema, the lungs of patients with cardiac tamponade are usually clear. Apical impulse is non localised with muffled heart sound due to the fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac.S3 is not found in cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 50 year old man, farmer by occupation presented to emergency with complaints of excessive salivation, loose motions and increased frequency of urine for 2 days after he accidently had exposure of insecticide filled bag on his face while working in the field. He also complaint of visual blurring.He is developing dyspnea for 5-6 hours.On examination pulse rate is 50/minute,BP-90/60,pupils are constricted.Chest auscultation-bilateral ronchi.What will be the next immediate step
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

IV atropine

The clinical features and history of exposure are suggestive of organophosphorus poisoning.It inhibits acetylcholinesterase,hence increasing actylcholine with its muscarinic effects like salivation,sweating,loose stools and pupil constriction.IV atropine will temporary improve these effects.

questions.text: A 70 year old man with heavy alcohol intake developed dilated cardiomyopathy. He was started on ace inhibitors, carvedilol and digoxin. He didn’t get regular follow up and now presented with palpitations. Lab reports- elevated BUN and serum creatinine, serum K- 5.8 meq/L.His ECG is shown in figure.What is the likely cause of these ECG changes.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Digoxin

This ECG is showing ST depression- “Hockey Stick” sign due to digoxin effect.Hyperkalemia will show ST narrowing on ECG.Alcohol causes atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: An intern working in a hepatitis ward accidently got needle stick injury from hepatitis B positive patient while taking a blood sample.Intern is vaccinated 5 years back during entry into medical college.His serum anti HbS levels are 50 mIU/ml.What will be done to prevent the risk of infection
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Nothing to be done

After needle stick injury in a fully vaccinated individual if anti Hbs levels are < 10 mIU/ml then booster dose of vaccine to be given,if anti Hbs levels are > 10 mIU/ml then nothing to be done.

questions.text: A 40 year old female consumed 20 tablets of aspirin after stressful event.Her husband took her  to emergency department after 12 hours .On examination vitals are stable,per abdomen-epigastric tenderness present. Lab reports- blood pH 7.31, HCO3- 20 meq/L, PaCO2-36 mmHg,serum Na 145 meq/L,serum chloride-109,serum K-4.2 meq/L.What is the most likely acid base abnormality present
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Low pH and low HCO3/low paCO2 are indicating metabolic acidosis. Anion gap (Na-(hco3_Cl)),here is 145-129 = 16, which is high. Normal AG is 10-14.This high anion gap metabolic acidosis is due to salicylate poisoning.

questions.text: A 23 year old woman presents with 8-month history of bloating, loose stool and bowel-opening frequency of 3 times per day. There is no weight loss and no blood in stools. No history of fever. Blood tests reveal a haemoglobin of 10 g/dL, a ferritin of 7 µg/L(low) and a folate of 1 µg/L(low). What is the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Given the duration of the symptoms, this is not likely to be infection. Given the constellation of symptoms, anaemia , low ferritin and low folate in a patient of this age, coeliac disease(proximal small intestine is affected which leads to deficiency of iron and folic acid) should be considered initially and therefore coeliac serology is the next best investigation.
